data.text: Do You Keep Your Bicycle in the Tent when Camping?
What tent do people use when travelling solo with their bike? Do you put your bike in your tent or under a tarp when wild camping? Thanks in advance 😊
I leave my bike out generally. If it's a rainy trip I may bring a little ripstop to throw over it.
data.author: David Baker-Yuill

data.text: I’m using a Vango banshee 200, 2.5kg, pitch in 5 mins with practice, good shade of green for stealth camping. Bike wise I just leave it outside either laying down or against a tree if I’m hiding in woods
data.author: Keith Warner

data.text: Forgot to put a photo up
data.author: Keith Warner

data.text: me too!
data.author: Michael Christopher Burkey

data.text: One wheel in the tent and the bike outside, under a tarp if wet. If I'm in an area where I feel it's more likely to be stolen, I have a lightweight cafe lock that I can use to attach the bike to one of the tent peg loops. It wouldn't stop someone getting away with the bike - but it would wake me up to shout at them/chase them/pretend to be a grizzly.
data.author: Linz Smith

data.text: I currently use a Big Agnes copper Spur. I don't put my bike in or under anything when camping..
data.author: Michael Viglianco

data.text: Nemo Hornet 2p. I just cover the seat. Otherwise water isn’t going to hurt it.
data.author: Ty Dawley

data.text: I use the Big Agnes Copper Spur ul 1 and think it’s great. Bike stays outside. I carry a little cable and padlock if needed but also won’t stop anyone but would give me a few seconds of alert. I carry a poncho for me in the rain and will cover the bike if it rains at night.
data.author: Brian Gangelhoff

data.text: I carry this awesome bike cover made by Arkel. Works great, I leave my panniers on also.

data.text: I use one place tent, I leave my bike beside the door of the tent, and cover it with tarp, I rarely tie it.
data.author: غويلب محمد رضا

data.text: ZPacks Plexamid. Bike stays outside, sometimes on side with front wheel inside vestibule. (No tent poles. Pic shows trekking pole when backpacking, but I use a carbon straight pole when bikepacking that Zpacks sells.)
data.author: Tracy Fawns

data.text: I have a Marmont UL 2P that I love. Very light for a two person and the vestibules on each side are great for convenience and ventilation. Also the rain fly is great and there are no seepage issues even if you don't use the ground cover (but I never pitched it in a water sink. Packs up super small if you just carry the poles on the outside of your bike. Only detraction is the bright green color is pretty visible if you're stealth camping.
data.author: Connor Allen

data.text: We carried an old tent footprint and covered our bikes at night. Always felt it was a bit of an alarm as well. ..If someone had to pull it off we’d hear it
data.author: Sue Sommers

data.text: I leave it outside. Lock it and that’s the lot. A tent is not going to protect it!
data.author: Steve Copeland

data.text: I just locked my bike to a tree.
data.author: Velo Roo

data.text: I carry a cheap tent from big 5 box store. It’s just big enough to fit me and a nightly necessities, but small enough and the right colors to be stealthy. My bike goes behind my tent, under a small tarp if it rains, but always locked and I lash a bungee from the bike to a tent pole, just in case.
data.author: Nesta Skychild
Nesta Skychild

data.text: This is a problem that stops me from bikepacking ..getting my bike stolen
data.author: Doug Brett

data.text: just get out there, how many bikes get stolen while your in the middle of nowhere bike packing? answer hardly any. The risk is minimal not worth thinking about.
data.author: Bill Richards

data.text: I've just ridden for the last 10 months 13k not locked my bike once. Cycled to Asia and back through Europe.
data.author: Hekta Burnz

data.text: Depends where you're touring but I stopped locking up my bike in rural France when I saw that none of the locals did. Different matter in towns of course but in St Mâlo I saw whole touring rigs just chained to bike stands - bags and panniers still attached. We started doing the same, just taking our bar bags with us.
data.author: Jon Mathias

data.text: I usually just lock it up to something. Although one night when I camped on the beach there was nowhere to do that so I wrapped the chain around both tires and locked it like that.
data.author: Olivia Kibbe

data.text: DIY tarp.for me .... And mybike just stays outside, usually.
data.author: TC Rboert Dawson

data.text: I like Big Agnes tents. Bike stays outside with a seat cover if wet.
data.author: Paul Lieberman

data.text: I've used a few different 2 person tents, My bike stays out, don't even remove the panniers unless rain is predicted, then move them to the vestibule. Usually just zip them up. I covered my seat when riding a leather saddle.
data.author: Whit Elfner

data.text: MSR Hubba Hubba. 2 person. Room inside for panniers. Can be expanded nicely with addition of MSR gear shed if you need more space for gear or another person.
data.author: Bruce Powell

data.text: I've literally just bought one. When it arrived, I assumed the package was something else as it was so light. My wife and I each have an MSR Freelite 1 (she does mostly walking whereas I mostly cycle) so we do go on solo trips. However, she got into cycling last year, so we travel together now. I lost a lot of weight recently, so my snoring has stopped and she can once again bear to share a tent with me. 😜
data.author: Jon Mathias

data.text: Wechsel Tempest 3, very big tent for 1, but very light and small when packed. Only 2,850 kilo Bicycle always inside Pic from in the shop, fitting the bicycle in the tent
data.author: Chris De Backer

data.text: I think the gist of what people are saying is that even when traveling solo, bring a lightweight 2 person tent, and don't bring your bike inside, that's just crazy.
data.author: James Reilly

data.text: Your bike is outdoors all day long, days or even weeks at a time as you ride on tour. No need for bike pajamas. Just cover your seat and keep everything properly lubed. Bike thieves hang out at coffee houses, college dorms, and shopping mall, not off in the woods, remote and far away.
data.author: Richard Mitchell

data.text: I tie it with my backpack and put my pack pack inside the tent So if someone tried to steal it he is going to pull the backpack and wake me up
data.author: Sid Ahmed

data.text: I took a 2 person tent on my last tour. I used my poncho over the bike. I stayed in campgrounds. So I just locked my bike to trees.
data.author: Jean Phillips

data.text: Marmot Tungsten UL. lite and roomy. I spent enough time with my bike. My wife would not understand if I shared my tent with it. Soooo the bike stays just outside the tent locked up.😀
data.author: Leonard Slye

data.text: MSR Hubba. I sometimes put the derailleur under my fly but mostly let my bike stay uncovered in the weather. If I have any doubts, I lock it up.
data.author: Meghan Fitz-James

data.text: I wrap one of the guy ropes around the bike (and still peg it into the ground). Not taking the bike without affecting the tent. Also make the thief look for another target 😉
data.author: Steve Heaton

data.text: I have a Tarptent Protrail for overnights - 1 person tent. But prefer the Tarptent Stratospire 2 for longer. Very roomy, dual vestibules for my bags. Bike stays outside. Plastic bag on seat to prevent condensation on it. Can always put a releasable ziptie on the wheel if you're worried about your bike.
data.author: Pamela Murray

data.text: O just leave my bike outside. But I attach it to my tent with a paracord
data.author: Gert Pellin

data.text: I sleep in a hammock under a tarp with the bike underneath the hammock with the gear
data.author: Rob Dinsmore

data.text: You remove both wheels, and join them through a common axle with 2.5 ft apart. Now you place the fork on the axle and tie ends of handle with wheels, left and right corresponding. Now you cover this arrangement with tent, you can slide below axle, with end of cycle either in centre of legs or on one side, or you can have a aluminium stand to fit in-place of rear wheel. No way bike can be stolen. You can DM me for more info. I am not a seller, but I will guide you to make one. It's easy to carry and far better than other arrangements.
data.author: Balraj Singh

data.author: Carol Zimmer Clark

data.text: I'm currently using an old Terra Nova Solar 2,with additional lightweight alloy tent pegs
data.author: Colin Ainscough

data.text: I usually stealth camp so no need to be over concerned about locking my bike, although I will usually leash it to a tree! my tent of choice is a 2 man MSR, it’s a great tent with brilliant ventilation and plenty of vestibule storage for your bits and pieces, it’s not leaked (yet) and it’s easy to put up and down, not the cheapest but not the most expensive either… happy touring, peace ☮️
data.author: Ed Gee-wing

data.text: Touring, I have a two person tent. Lots to choose from The one I have now has one large vestibule. I could partially cover the bike. I also have a military poncho, which is big enough to cover most of the bike. I am about to start playing around with bike packing and got an almost unused second hand one person tent. I will carry the poncho to start with, but it may be excess weight for bike packing. I am always refining, tinkering with something.
data.author: Mark Perry

data.text: Bike stays outside.
data.author: Doug Ford

data.text: MSR Freelite 1. Easy to pitch, never any leaks or condensation and 1.29kg including footprint and bags. I use a combination of bikepacking bags and rear panniers, so have a rear rack. Tent is strapped on the top of the rack. First thing off the bike, last thing on. Bike always stays outside. Might chain it to a tree if I can be bothered.
data.author: Jon Mathias

data.text: For years I used a Big Agnes Seedhouse LP2 and it finally died on tour after 11 years. Always said I hated the one door/one vestibule tent-crawling over your stuff trying to get in and out. While on tour last year, I replaced it with a Sea to Summit Telos TR2. Had a choice of 3 different 2-door lightweight tents and chose S2S. Love the two door/vestibule and wide ceiling.
data.author: Joyce Riecker
